meanings.definition: To reduce to atoms or small particles.
meanings.sent1: The scientist used a powerful machine to atomise the metal into tiny pieces.
meanings.sent2: When you crush a rock, you atomise it into smaller bits.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally pressed the wrong button and ended up atomising my sandwich into crumbs.
meanings.sent4: The explosion was so intense that it seemed to atomise the entire building into dust.
meanings.sent5: The blender was so strong that it could atomise any fruit you put in it.

meanings.definition: To break down into smaller components.
meanings.sent1: The digestive system helps to atomise food into nutrients for the body.
meanings.sent2: Over time, the old building started to atomise into pieces due to neglect.
meanings.sent3: The teacher's explanation was so confusing that it seemed to atomise the students' understanding.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brushstrokes seemed to atomise the painting into intricate details.
meanings.sent5: The rain began to atomise the dirt on the window, creating streaks of mud.

meanings.sent1: The old bridge began to atomise under the weight of the heavy truck.
meanings.sent2: Leaving a metal object in water for too long can cause it to atomise over time.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick made it seem like he could atomise objects with just a wave of his hand.
meanings.sent4: The tension in the room was so palpable that it felt like it could atomise at any moment.
meanings.sent5: The intense heat caused the ice sculpture to slowly atomise into a puddle.
